intro: Matelea coriacea, commonly known as the roughleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy, rough-textured leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. Its unique morphology and adaptive traits make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
